This post will examine the Polish government’s refusal to implement the recommendations adopted by the Commission on 27 July 2016. Poland had three months to implement these recommendations in order to address the systemic threat to the rule of law identified by the Commission. The different options available to the Commission will then be briefly explored, the most dramatic of which is a possible recourse to Article 7 TEU, the provision empowering EU institutions, under certain demanding conditions, to suspend inter alia the voting rights of the relevant national government in the Council of the EU.

On Thursday, 27 October, the deadline set by the European Commission for Poland to comply with the Commission’s Rule of Law Recommendation expires. The Recommendation requires the Polish government to publish all decisions of the Constitutional Court and follow them. First Vice-President Frans Timmermans said in July:
"Despite the dialogue pursued with the Polish authorities since the beginning of the year, the Commission considers the main issues which threaten the rule of law in Poland have not been resolved. We are therefore now making concrete recommendations to the Polish authorities on how to address the concerns so that the Constitutional Tribunal of Poland can carry out its mandate to deliver effective constitutional review." The Polish Government has offered some concessions, but — with less than a month to go before the threatened sanctions — Timmermans has told the European Parliament in Strasbourg on Tuesday (September 27): "At this stage, the dispute concerning the composition and the judgments of the constitutional of the tribunal remains unresolved."

Brussels Gives Poland Three Months To Apply Rule-Of-Law Recommendations 
http://www.rferl.org/content/poland-eu-rule-of-law-recommendations-three-months/27885710.html

The European Commission has today adopted a Rule of Law Recommendation on the situation in Poland, setting out the Commission's concerns and recommending how these can be addressed.
This new step under the Rule of Law Framework follows the intensive dialogue that has been ongoing with the Polish authorities since 13 January. After the adoption of an Opinion on the situation in Poland on 1 June, the Polish Parliament adopted a new Law on the Constitutional Tribunal on 22 July. The Commission has assessed the overall situation, including in the light of the new law, and reaches the conclusion that even if certain of its concerns have been addressed by that law, important issues of concern regarding the rule of law in Poland remain. The Commission is therefore laying out concrete recommendations to the Polish authorities on how to address these concerns.
The Commission believes that there is a systemic threat to the rule of law in Poland. The fact that the Constitutional Tribunal is prevented from fully ensuring an effective constitutional review adversely affects its integrity, stability and proper functioning, which is one of the essential safeguards of the rule of law in Poland. Where a constitutional justice system has been established, its effectiveness is a key component of the rule of law (¶ 1-3).

This seems very unlikely to me.  What is actually at issue here?  At present, the constitutional tribunal in Poland can block legislation with a simple majority if it deems new laws to be unconstitutional. The government wants to change this to a two-third majority requirement. This will make parliament more powerful relative to the court, that's true, and this is currently to the benefit of the ruling party, but is this somehow so radically anti-democratic that the EU needs to make some stand?  I severely doubt this. The EU has much  bigger problems at hand and needs Poland's cooperation on a range of issues.  In any case, such a move by the EU would likely require a substantial approval process that could easily take us beyond the end of the year.

Three important reasons this is likely to not happen: first of all it would require a unanimous vote between the government in the Council in at least one state of the voting procedures and this unanimous voting precedent is highly likely to deter the decision. Second the EU has never actually suspended violators of the Union because of the obstacles that require to do such an action and it is highly unlikely that it would occur this year, in this economic climate, and to Poland of all countries. Thirdly and most importantly, the suspension of Poland from the EU would be costly for the organization.

I received a comment on my very brief post, noting my article may be insufficient support for a zero probability.  I would first note that three rationales can be compelling enough for a zero probability.  Even one could if compelling enough.  To wit:
"1. Institutional rules matter.
First, we find that when international organizations have high voting thresholds for suspension, itâ€™s less likely to happen. In the case of the E.U. and Poland, suspension would require unanimity among the heads of government in the Council in at least one stage of the voting procedures. Hungary alone could block this suspension vote."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2016/01/21/will-the-e-u-suspend-poland-here-are-3-reasons-it-wont/

The crisis in Poland isn't fairly new to the nation, nor should it be a cause for panic for the European Union. In fact, the Civic Platform when the held the majority in the Parliament in the last cycle tried to stack the court and implement there own "reforms" which were than overruled by the Constitution Tribunal. The one difference in both these scenario's is that the Civic Party accepted and published the courts ruling  while the Law and Justice Party is choosing to ignore and not publish the courts ruling.
The EU bringing up the possibility alone was the real threat, and not any realistic possibility of it happening.
Initial forecast: I would think this to be very unlikely, but I will put a marker in at 1%.

Most highly unlikely given factors mentioned by @Khalid and others.

This is a generalization, but I think it is an unintended consequence of adding former Iron Curtain countries to the EU. Sober democracy hasn’t had much time to properly set in, so to speak, since the 1990s. I’m not sure the contingency of extremist populist political parties winning elections was factored into decision making until recently. I don’t think suspending Polish membership is the way to go, but behind the scenes maneuvering will ramp up.

Well, it didn't for Hungary, and the Union is fragile right now. The second step in the process to suspend some membership right(s) requires the "consent of the European Parliament". I assume that means a majority vote in Parliament. That seems like an obstacle to me. It's not easy to get a group of politicians with disparate goals, interests, relationships with Poland to agree on a controversial action that might make other Eastern European and Baltic nations think twice about joining the EU.

1) The formal review process is already an unprecedented act. So while there is no base case for suspension of voting rights, there is also no base case for how this review process works or the likihood that it leads to the next step.

Starting at zero, after reading earlier comments. The EU is not known for taking quick decisions, so it seems safe to predict such a momentous one would need more than the nine months remaining this year. As pointed out by @Dima-K below, the initial identification of a breach of EU's values would require a unanimous decision of the European Council (excluding the member state), and Poland probably has enough friends among EU's "New Europe" members to prevent that.

As other comments have said the EU does not want to be seen to be bullying an elected government in a member state, but equally the Polish government may see that the consequences of trying to change its constitutional balance between government, courts, freedom of expression etc. could create more problems (e.g. spooking foreign investors, anti-government protests, annoying the US etc.). So a compromise (partial climb down by the Polish government) is more likely than an escalation.
Placeholder. May prove somewhat interesting, but a waste to the extent scoring matters.

Unless significant info is missing, the three step process requiring a 2/3 majority, the presence of Hungary, and others, also with active authoritarian governments, Poland's economic strength in the EU, plenty of time for negotiations and many other options to influence behavior - it seems improbable that membership rights will be suspended.
Going by @Dima-K  on unanimous vote necessity.  Romania and Bulgaria won't agree, lest they be next.

At that, failure is highly likely, though they will try by any means, nontheless.
